results.title: Overnight in Walmart Parking Lots: Silence, Solace and Refuge
results.abstract: Walmart’s practice of letting people populate many of its parking lots has made the retail giant’s stores a reliable destination and a place where an informal culture emerges before and after dark.

multimedia.caption: “You’re going to see a lot of folks out here running from something,” said a man who identified himself only as Sunny. He posed with a stuffed animal of an amphibian named Fabian for a portrait in his R.V. in a Walmart parking lot in Asheville, N.C. He added: “For the first time in my live I’m not running from anything. I guess I was running from myself.” Sunny travels the country, but spends the in-between time in Asheville. This particular Walmart stopped allowing overnight stays months ago, Sunny said, so he spends afternoon and evenings there before moving elsewhere to spend the night.

results.title: The Secret to Long Life? It May Lurk in the DNA of the Oldest Among Us
results.abstract: James Clement has scoured the globe for supercentenarians, aged 110 and older, willing to contribute their genomes to a rare scientific cache.

multimedia.caption: Clarence Matthews, 110, had blood drawn at his home in Indian Wells, Calif., last year, part of a project to examine the genes of the very old. Mr. Matthews died a few months ago.
multimedia.copyright: Ivan Kashinsky for The New York Times

results.title: A Race to Save 10 Stranded Whales
results.abstract: Long after sunset, local officials and nonprofits worked to rescue a pod of whales that had become stranded off the coast of Indonesia.

multimedia.caption: A drone camera showed nine of the 10 whales that were stranded off the coast of Indonesia on Monday.
A drone camera showed nine of the 10 whales that were stranded off the coast of Indonesia on Monday.

results.title: Taking Care of the Physician
results.abstract: A growing body of research literature shows that physician burnout and depression are linked to medical errors and depersonalized care.

results.title: What Explains U.S. Mass Shootings? International Comparisons Suggest an Answer
results.abstract: Americans advance a lot of theories for why they have so many more gun deaths than other countries do. The answer is lying in plain sight.
results.byline: By MAX FISHER and JOSH KELLER

results.title: Anniversary of the Apocalypse
results.abstract: The once-unthinkable is becoming ordinary.

results.title: At the Met Opera, a Note So High, It’s Never Been Sung Before
results.abstract: It’s an A above high C — the equivalent of a pole vault to the sun. Few performers can hit it, but it’s a requirement in “The Exterminating Angel.”

multimedia.caption: Audrey Luna, with (background, from left) John Tomlinson, Frédéric Antoun and David Adam Moore in “The Exterminating Angel” at the Metropolitan Opera.
multimedia.copyright: Emon Hassan for The New York Times

results.title: Air Travelers Resisting the ‘Incredible Shrinking Airline Seat’
results.abstract: Thinner, smaller airline seats have allowed carriers to squeeze in more passengers. But travelers have begun to rebel against reduced legroom, citing safety.

multimedia.caption: Passengers aboard an Allegiant Air flight. Many small and large carriers have been finding ways to put more, smaller seats in cabins.
multimedia.copyright: Joe Giron for The New York Times
